title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
library(tidyverse)
random_vars <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")

# Compute the expected value, variance and standard deviation for variable age
mean_age <- mean(random_vars$age)
mean_age

#> [1] 33.471

var_age <- var(random_vars$age)
var_age

#> [1] 340.6078

sd_age <- sd(random_vars$age)
sd_age

#> [1] 18.45556

#Compute the expected value, variance and standard deviation for variable income
mean_income <- mean(random_vars$income)
mean_income

#> [1] 3510.731

var_income <- var(random_vars$income)
var_income

#> [1] 8625646

sd_income <- sd(random_vars$income)
sd_income

#> [1] 2936.945




Age expected value: 33.471
Age variance: 340.6078
Age standard deviation: 18.45556
Income expected value: 3510.731
Income variance: 8625646
Income standard deviation: 2936.945


It doesn’t make sense to compare them since they are individual data sets and the comparison would give us no insight.


#Compute the covariance and correlation between both variables
covariance <- cov(random_vars$age,random_vars$income)
covariance

#> [1] 29700.15

correlation <- cor(random_vars$age,random_vars$income)
correlation

#> [1] 0.5479432




Covariance: 29700.15

Correlation: 0.5479432


Covariance indicates the direction of the linear relationship between variables but it doesn’t provide a standardized measure.
Correlation is a standardized measure that ranges between -1 and 1. With -1 indicating a perfect negative linear relationship, 0 indicating no linear relationship and 1 indicating a perfect positive linear relationship.
With the description above, it is easier to interpret the correlation since the values are fixed and we know that the 0.5479 represents a strong linear relation because it is closer to 1. The covariance value since it has no standardized measure, we are unable to know if it is representing a high or low value.



\(E[income|age<=18]\)

\(E[income|age\in[18,65)]\)
\(E[income|age>=65]\)


cev1<- filter(random_vars,age<=18)
mean_cev1 <- mean(cev1$income)
mean_cev1

#> [1] 389.6074

cev2<- filter(random_vars,age>=18&age<65)
mean_cev2 <- mean(cev2$income)
mean_cev2

#> [1] 4685.734

cev3<- filter(random_vars,age>=65)
mean_cev3<- mean(cev3$income)
mean_cev3

#> [1] 1777.237





\(E[income|age<=18]= 389.6074\)

\(E[income|age\in[18,65)]=4685.734\)
\(E[income|age>=65]=1777.237\)

title: Causality
text:
Per capita cheese consumption correlates with Number of people who died by becoming tangled in their bedsheets.

library(gridExtra)
# With 10 coordinates from out plot:

cheese_consumption <- c(29.8, 30.1, 30.5, 30.6, 31.3, 31.7, 32.6, 33.1, 32.7, 32.8)
bedsheet_deaths <- c(327, 456, 509, 497, 596, 573, 661, 741, 809, 717)

# Create a data frame
data <- data.frame(Year = seq(2000, 2009), Cheese = cheese_consumption, Bedsheets = bedsheet_deaths)

# Load ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)

# Create a plot for Cheese Consumption
plot_cheese <- ggplot(data, aes(x = Year, y = Cheese)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_line(color = "blue", linetype = "solid") +
  labs(title = "Cheese Consumption Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Cheese Consumption")

# Create a plot for Bedsheet Deaths
plot_bedsheets <- ggplot(data, aes(x = Year, y = Bedsheets)) +
  geom_point(color = "red") +
  geom_line(color = "red", linetype = "dashed") +
  labs(title = "Bedsheet Deaths Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Bedsheet Deaths")

# Display the plots side by side
gridExtra::grid.arrange(plot_cheese, plot_bedsheets, ncol = 2)

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
Imagine the following situation: you have developed an app and you are already having an active user base. Of course, some users are more active than other users. Also, users might use the app for different purposes. In general, user behavior likely depends on a lot of unobserved characteristics.
Obviously, your goal is to keep users as long as possible on the app to maximize your ad revenues. To do that, you want to introduce a new feature and see how it affects time spent on the app. Simply comparing users who use the newly introduced feature to users who don’t would result in a biased estimate due to the unobserved confounders regarding their activity and willingness to use a new feature.
Therefore, you perform a so called randomized encouragement trial, where for a random selection of users, a popup appears when opening the app and encourages these users to test new feature. The users who are not randomly selected don’t get a popup message but could also use the new feature.
After a while you collect data on users’ activity and also if they were encouraged and if they used the new feature.




NF: New Feature
PU: Pop Up
UC: Unobserved Characteristics
ST: Screen Time


library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(estimatr)

#Load the data
App <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/rand_enc.rds")

# Define DAG
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
NF [avgpur,pos="0.7,0.4"]
UC [preavgpur,pos="0.8,0.6"]
ST [card,pos="0.9,0.4"]
PU [pos="0.6,0.4"]

UC-> NF
UC -> ST
NF -> ST
NF -> PU


}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag()+
  geom_dag_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "white") +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "green")









#Compute the naive, biased estimate
lm_naive <- lm(time_spent ~ used_ftr, data = App)
summary(lm_naive)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = time_spent ~ used_ftr, data = App)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -20.4950  -3.5393   0.0158   3.5961  20.5051 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) 18.86993    0.06955   271.3   <2e-16 ***
#> used_ftr    10.82269    0.10888    99.4   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 5.351 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.497,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.497 
#> F-statistic:  9881 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16




#Correlation computation
cor_matrix <- cor(App)
print(cor_matrix)

#>             rand_enc  used_ftr time_spent
#> rand_enc   1.0000000 0.2044110  0.1296716
#> used_ftr   0.2044110 1.0000000  0.7050147
#> time_spent 0.1296716 0.7050147  1.0000000

app_corr <- App %>%
  filter(used_ftr == 1)
cor(app_corr$rand_enc,app_corr$time_spent)

#> [1] -0.02744462

#First Stage
first_stage <- lm(used_ftr~time_spent, data = App)
summary(first_stage)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = used_ftr ~ time_spent, data = App)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -1.1469 -0.2593 -0.0247  0.2592  1.1636 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) -0.661420   0.011309  -58.48   <2e-16 ***
#> time_spent   0.045926   0.000462   99.40   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 0.3486 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.497,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.497 
#> F-statistic:  9881 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

# Predicted 'probabilities' from first stage
pred_fs <- predict(first_stage)

# Create table with predictions and actual decisions
pred_vs_actl <- tibble(
  pred = pred_fs,
  actl = App$used_ftr
)

# Plot predictions vs original
ggplot(pred_vs_actl, aes(x = pred, y = actl, color = as.factor(actl))) +
  geom_jitter(alpha = .5) +
  scale_color_discrete(labels = c("Control Group", "Treatment Group")) +
  theme(legend.title = element_blank())






# Second stage
second_stage <- lm(App$time_spent ~ first_stage$fitted.values)
summary(second_stage)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = App$time_spent ~ first_stage$fitted.values)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>       Min        1Q    Median        3Q       Max 
#> -8.30e-15 -1.40e-15 -7.00e-16 -1.00e-16  5.58e-12 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                            Estimate Std. Error   t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)               1.440e+01  8.900e-16 1.618e+16   <2e-16 ***
#> first_stage$fitted.values 2.177e+01  1.663e-15 1.309e+16   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 5.761e-14 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:      1,  Adjusted R-squared:      1 
#> F-statistic: 1.715e+32 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



IV estimation can provide more credible causal estimates if the 5-prerequisites (Stable unit treatment value assumption, Independence assumption, Exclusion restriction, Instrument relevance and Monotonicity assumption) are met.


model_iv <- iv_robust(time_spent ~ used_ftr | rand_enc, data = App)
summary(model_iv)

#> 
#> Call:
#> iv_robust(formula = time_spent ~ used_ftr | rand_enc, data = App)
#> 
#> Standard error type:  HC2 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value  Pr(>|t|) CI Lower CI Upper   DF
#> (Intercept)   19.312     0.2248   85.89 0.000e+00   18.872    19.75 9998
#> used_ftr       9.738     0.5353   18.19 8.716e-73    8.689    10.79 9998
#> 
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.4921 ,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.492 
#> F-statistic:   331 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



coefIV<- coef(model_iv)
print(coefIV)

#> (Intercept)    used_ftr 
#>   19.312415    9.738175

coefNB<- coef(lm_naive)
print(coefNB)

#> (Intercept)    used_ftr 
#>    18.86993    10.82269



The naive estimate is biased if there are unobserved confounders influencing both the treatment assignment and the outcome. The instrumental variable estimate aims to address this bias by using an instrument that is correlated with the treatment but is not directly related to the outcome, except through its effect on the treatment.
Comparing these estimates, it seems that the naive estimate is larger than the IV estimate. If the instrument is valid (i.e., it satisfies the necessary assumptions), the IV estimate is often considered less biased than the naive estimate. Therefore, it is possible that the naive estimate has an upward bias.

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
You are running an online store and one year ago, you introduced a plus membership to bind customers to your store and increase revenue. The plus memberships comes at a small cost for the customers, which is why not all of the customers subscribed. Now you want to examine whether binding customers by this membership program in fact increases your sales with subscribed customers. But of course, there are potentially confounding variables such as age, sex or pre_avg_purch (previous average purchases).




C -> card
A -> age
S -> sex
PAP -> Pre Average Purchase (pre_abg_purch)
AP -> Average Purchase (avg_purch)


library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(ggplot2)
library(MatchIt)
library(tidyverse)
# Load the dataset
membership_data <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/membership.rds")

# Define DAG
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
AP [avgpur,pos="0.9,0.6"]
PAP [preavgpur,pos="0.6,0.4"]
C [card,pos="0.9,0.4"]
A [pos="0.7,0.6"]
S [pos="0.7,0.2"]

C-> AP
PAP -> C
A-> C
S-> C
A-> PAP
S -> PAP

}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag()+
  geom_dag_point(color = "pink") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "red")









lm_model <- lm(avg_purch ~  card, data = membership_data)
summary(lm_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = membership_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -101.515  -20.684   -0.199   20.424  120.166 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  65.9397     0.3965  166.29   <2e-16 ***
#> card         25.2195     0.6095   41.38   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 30.11 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.1462, Adjusted R-squared:  0.1461 
#> F-statistic:  1712 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

coefficients <- coef(lm_model)
print(coefficients)

#> (Intercept)        card 
#>    65.93965    25.21950




(Coarsened) Exact Matching.


#CEM
cem <- matchit(card ~ avg_purch + age + pre_avg_purch + sex,
               data = membership_data, 
               method = 'cem', 
               estimand = 'ATE')
df_cem <- match.data(cem)
model_cem<- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
summary (model_cem)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -162.422  -19.058    0.153   18.795  147.646 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  75.9624     0.4051 187.526   <2e-16 ***
#> card          0.9485     0.6212   1.527    0.127    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 28.34 on 8515 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0002737,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.0001563 
#> F-statistic: 2.332 on 1 and 8515 DF,  p-value: 0.1268



Nearest-Neighbor Matching.


#Nearest Neighbor
nn <- matchit(card ~ avg_purch + pre_avg_purch + sex + age,
              data = membership_data,
              method = "nearest", # changed
              distance = "mahalanobis", # changed
              replace = T)
df_nn <- match.data(nn)
nn_model <- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df_nn, weights = weights)
summary(nn_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_nn, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -101.515  -22.370   -3.279   16.475  178.481 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  90.2268     0.6438 140.155   <2e-16 ***
#> card          0.9324     0.7939   1.174     0.24    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 30.22 on 6434 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0002143,  Adjusted R-squared:  5.895e-05 
#> F-statistic: 1.379 on 1 and 6434 DF,  p-value: 0.2403



Inverse Probability Weighting.


# Inverse Probability Weighting
model_prop <- glm(card ~ avg_purch + sex + age + pre_avg_purch,
                  data=membership_data,
                  family = binomial(link="logit"))
df_aug <- membership_data %>% mutate(propensity = predict(model_prop, type = "response"))

#Extend data by IPW scores:
df_ipw <- df_aug %>% mutate(
  ipw = (card/propensity) + ((1-card) / (1-propensity)))

#Estimation
model_ipw <- lm(avg_purch ~ card,
                data = df_ipw, 
                weights = ipw)
summary(model_ipw)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_ipw, weights = ipw)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -525.64  -28.55   -0.11   30.04  441.02 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  76.5744     0.4664 164.189   <2e-16 ***
#> card         -0.6361     0.6577  -0.967    0.333    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 46.6 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  9.356e-05,  Adjusted R-squared:  -6.45e-06 
#> F-statistic: 0.9355 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: 0.3335

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
Imagine you are a business owner of four stores and you want to investigate if there is a benefit of having own parking spots in front of your store. And if there is a benefit, you would also like to know what size it has.
At stores A and B, which are located in the city center, you don’t have any parking spots but at stores. C and D, located outside the city you do. Except for location and parking spots, the stores are very similar, i.e. they sell exactly the same goods, have the same size etc.

Variables:

L-> Location

P-> Parking Spots

A-> Store A
B-> Store B
C-> Store C
D-> Store D
S-> Sales


library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

# create DAG from dagitty
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
L [location,pos="0.9,0.6"]
P [exposure,pos="0.575,0.4"]
S [outcome,pos="0.9,0.4"]
D [pos="0.7,0.2"]
C [pos="0.7,0.3"]
B [pos="0.7,0.5"]
A [pos="0.7,0.6"]
L-> S
P -> B
P-> A
P-> C
P-> D
A -> S
B -> S
C -> S
D -> S
}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag()+
  geom_dag_point(color = "pink") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "black") +
    geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "blue")









A company sells a SaaS (Software as a service) to business clients that chose to subscribe to one of the three subscription levels, Starter, Premium or Elite, which provide different features at different price points (more storage and other capabilities). Starter has the least functionality, while Elite includes the most features.

Now imagine, you are working as an analyst for that company and are asked to examine the relationship between follow-up calls to the clients and their satisfaction with the product and service. Follow-up calls are voluntary and are just to help the client with possible problems and so on. Satisfaction is measured on a weekly basis by surveying the clients.




df <- data.frame(
  follow_ups = c(8, 7, 8, 9, 10, 6, 7, 6, 8, 8, 0, 1, 2, 2, 3),
  satisfaction = c(40, 45, 47, 44, 50, 55, 60, 62, 59, 65, 70, 74, 77, 74, 80),
  subscription = c("Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium", "Premium", "Premium", "Premium", "Premium")
)

# Regress satisfaction on follow_ups
model_follow_ups <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
summary(model_follow_ups)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

summary(model_follow_ups)$coefficients["follow_ups", "Pr(>|t|)"]

#> [1] 0.0002426524

# Regress satisfaction on follow_ups and account for subscription
model_subscription <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df)
summary(model_subscription)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08

summary(model_subscription)$coefficients["follow_ups", "Pr(>|t|)"]

#> [1] 0.0168153




The coefficient for the satisfaction on follow ups is -3.3093
The coefficient for the satisfaction on follow ups and account for subscription is 2.1944

When follow ups are being done, the level of satisfaction on those is low which is why the coefficient is negative.
When you factor in the subscription the level of satisfaction increases which is why the coefficient is positive.
Since the follow ups are to help the client with possible problems, when they are following up maybe the problems are not solved and the satisfaction of the call would be low. When people have subscriptions their problems might be easier to solve and therefore the overall satisfaction would increase.


library(ggplot2)

# Scatter plot with regression line for satisfaction ~ follow_ups
plot_follow_ups <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(title = "Satisfaction vs. Follow-ups",
       x = "Follow-ups",
       y = "Satisfaction")

# Scatter plot with regression line for satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription
plot_subscription <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction, color = subscription)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Satisfaction vs. Follow-ups by Subscription",
       x = "Follow-ups",
       y = "Satisfaction",
       color = "Subscription")

# Display the plots
print(plot_follow_ups)

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'







print(plot_subscription)

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

# Load the dataset
abtest_data <-  readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/abtest_online.rds")
lm_ate <-lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data= abtest_data)
summary(lm_ate)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -16.702 -14.478  -9.626  13.922  64.648 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  16.7017     0.8374  19.944  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE  -7.0756     1.1796  -5.998 2.79e-09 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.65 on 998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0348, Adjusted R-squared:  0.03383 
#> F-statistic: 35.98 on 1 and 998 DF,  p-value: 2.787e-09

compare_prev <- ggplot(abtest_data,
                       aes(x=chatbot,
                           y=previous_visit,
                           color = as.factor(chatbot)))  + 
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Previous_visits", title = "Difference in previous visits")


compare_mobile <- ggplot(abtest_data,
                         aes(x=chatbot,
                             y=mobile_device,
                             color = as.factor(chatbot)))  + 
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Mobile decives", title = "Difference in mobile devices")


compare_outcome <-  ggplot(abtest_data, 
                           aes(x = chatbot, 
                               y = purchase_amount, 
                               color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Purchase Amount", title = "Difference in Purchase Amount")

plot(compare_prev)






plot (compare_mobile) 






plot(compare_outcome)








Covariates are not balanced in the plots.


lm_all <- lm(purchase_amount~chatbot+previous_visit+mobile_device, data=abtest_data)
summary(lm_all)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot + previous_visit + mobile_device, 
#>     data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -25.414 -14.428  -8.435  12.559  64.584 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)        15.2840     1.1227  13.614  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE        -6.8488     1.1792  -5.808 8.49e-09 ***
#> previous_visit      0.7792     0.2869   2.716  0.00673 ** 
#> mobile_deviceTRUE  -0.8562     1.2642  -0.677  0.49841    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.6 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04243,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03954 
#> F-statistic: 14.71 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 2.228e-09



We can see that the chatbot coefficient is negative and it has a small p value which would suggest that the chatbot is associated with a statistically significant decrease in the average purchase. Customers with the chatbot tend to make smaller purchases compared to those with human interaction.


# Include an interaction term
lm_model <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device, data = abtest_data)
summary(lm_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device, data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#> -16.98 -14.54  -9.95  14.13  65.24 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)                    16.9797     1.0152  16.725   <2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE                    -7.0301     1.4284  -4.922    1e-06 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE              -0.8727     1.7987  -0.485    0.628    
#> chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE  -0.1526     2.5369  -0.060    0.952    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.66 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.03534,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03244 
#> F-statistic: 12.16 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 8.034e-08



As we can see from the summary, both the estimate and p value show us that the interaction between chatbot and mobile users has no statistically significant effect on making a purchase.


#Logistic regression
logistic_model <- glm(purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
                      data = abtest_data, 
                      family = binomial(link = 'logit'))
summary(logistic_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)       -0.22185    0.12347  -1.797  0.07237 .  
#> chatbotTRUE       -0.96894    0.13564  -7.144 9.09e-13 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE -0.07119    0.14530  -0.490  0.62417    
#> previous_visit     0.10606    0.03262   3.252  0.00115 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 1329.1  on 999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 1262.2  on 996  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 1270.2
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4

# Extract coefficient for chatbot
chatbot_coefficient <- coef(logistic_model)["chatbotTRUE"]
# Calculate odds ratio
odds_ratio <- exp(chatbot_coefficient)


The coefficient for chatbot in the logistic model is -0.969 which means that for users that are exposed to the chatbot, the odds of making a purchase decrease by 0.969 units compared to those not exposed to it. If we exponentiate the coefficient will give us the odds ratio of 0.379 which tells us that the odds of making a purchase for users exposed to the chatbot are 0.379 times the odds for the users with human interaction.

title: Difference-in-Differences
text:
Imagine, you are manager of a large health provider that manages many hospitals and you want to test how a new admission procedure affects patient satisfaction. You randomly selected 18 hospitals that introduced the new admission procedure and compare them to 28 other hospitals that did not introduce the method. For both groups of hospitals you collected data from before and after the introduction. The data you have collected is from patient surveys where they were asked how satisfied they are.




library(tidyverse)

#Load the data 
Hospitals <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/hospdd.rds")

# Manually compute differences
# Step 1: Difference between treatment and control group BEFORE treatment
before_control_A <- Hospitals %>%
  filter(hospital >= 19 & hospital<= 46, procedure == 0) %>% 
  pull(satis)

before_treatment_A <- Hospitals %>%
  filter(hospital >= 1 & hospital<=18, procedure == 0) %>% 
  pull(satis)

diff_before_A <- before_treatment_A - before_control_A

#> Warning in before_treatment_A - before_control_A: longitud de objeto mayor no
#> es múltiplo de la longitud de uno menor

# Step 2: Difference between treatment and control group AFTER treatment
after_control_A <- rep(0, dim(Hospitals)[1])

after_treatment_A <- Hospitals  %>%
  filter(hospital >= 1 & hospital<=18, procedure == 1) %>% 
  pull(satis)

diff_after_A <- after_treatment_A - after_control_A

#> Warning in after_treatment_A - after_control_A: longitud de objeto mayor no es
#> múltiplo de la longitud de uno menor

# Step 3: Difference-in-differences.
diff_diff_A <- diff_after_A - diff_before_A

#> Warning in diff_after_A - diff_before_A: longitud de objeto mayor no es
#> múltiplo de la longitud de uno menor

sprintf("Estimate: %.2f", diff_diff_A)

month + hospital: treats months and hospitals as numeric variables and assumes a linear relationship between them. The coefficient estimation is separate for each month and hospital
as.factor treats the months and hospitals as factors which allows non-linear relationships. It estimates separate fixed effects for each month and hospital

library(tidyverse)
car <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")
dim_car <- dim(car)


How many rows does the data have: 181

How many columns does the data have: 22

Using the “glimpse()” command we got a more detailed look at the data which consists of numbers and characters. Numbers are represented as numeric values while strings are sequences of characters.

Looking at the summary from the linear regression, those factors that have a *** next to the p value represent the significance, so we will take those as relevant for pricing a car. The factors are the following:

Engine Type

Engine Size

Peak RPM

Stroke


lm_imp<- lm(price~enginetype+enginesize+peakrpm+stroke, data=car)
summary(lm_imp)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginetype + enginesize + peakrpm + stroke, 
#>     data = car)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -14872.1  -1453.3   -410.3   1563.4  10058.4 
#>

#>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)     -1.618e+04  4.220e+03  -3.834 0.000177 ***

#> enginetypel      3.842e+03  1.480e+03   2.596 0.010256 *

#> enginetypeohcf   6.534e+02  1.283e+03   0.509 0.611213    
#> enginetypeohcv  -4.967e+03  1.284e+03  -3.870 0.000154 ***
#> enginesize       2.145e+02  7.630e+00  28.106  < 2e-16 ***
#> peakrpm          3.400e+00  5.522e-01   6.158 5.05e-09 ***
#> stroke          -5.398e+03  9.088e+02  -5.939 1.55e-08 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#>

#> Multiple R-squared:  0.8704, Adjusted R-squared:  0.8644 
#> F-statistic: 144.4 on 8 and 172 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


With the code above we can see that the most relevant factor out of all was “engine size” since it has the smallest P-value and its the regressor we will use.


min(car$enginesize)

#> [1] 61

max(car$enginesize)

#> [1] 326



From the glimpse we know that the data type for “engine size” is a double.
The values it can take on we use the min and max functions to know the range of the “engine size”. From 61-326.


Since engine size was the most significant factor, having the lowest p value, which means the price is dependent on it and changing the value would affect the price, when the engine size increases, the price will increase as well.


A low p value provides support for the claim that the alternative hypothesis is true, which means there is a significant correlation between the variables.

title: Regression Discontinuity
text:
For the first assignment, use the data from the just discussed application (coupon.rds). When conducting a regression discontinuity design, one parameter that is chosen somehow arbitrarily is the bandwidth. Check how sensitive the result is to changing the bandwidth by running the analysis


library(tidyverse)

library(rddensity)

coupon <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/coupon.rds")

#define cut-off
c0 <- 60

# Define bandwidths
bw <- c0 + c(-5, 5) 
bw_1 <- c0 + c(-2.5,2,5) # Half BW
bw_2 <- c0 + c(-10,10)   # Double BW

# Normal Bandwidth:
# Subsets below and above threshold in specified bandwidth
df_bw_below <- coupon %>% filter(days_since_last >= bw[1] & days_since_last < c0)
df_bw_above <- coupon %>% filter(days_since_last >= c0 & days_since_last <= bw[2])

df_bw <- bind_rows(df_bw_above, df_bw_below)

lm_bw <- lm(purchase_after ~ days_since_last_centered + coupon, df_bw)
summary(lm_bw)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_after ~ days_since_last_centered + coupon, 
#>     data = df_bw)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -11.4966  -2.1312  -0.0949   2.0185  10.4159 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                          Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)               11.4242     0.3965  28.813  < 2e-16 ***
#> days_since_last_centered   0.3835     0.1259   3.046  0.00251 ** 
#> couponTRUE                 7.9334     0.7087  11.194  < 2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 3.186 on 320 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.7074, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7055 
#> F-statistic: 386.8 on 2 and 320 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16




# Case of Half the bandwidth
df_bw_below_1 <- coupon %>% filter(days_since_last >= bw_1[1] & days_since_last < c0)
df_bw_above_1 <- coupon %>% filter(days_since_last >= c0 & days_since_last <= bw_1[2])

df_bw_1 <- bind_rows(df_bw_above_1, df_bw_below_1)

lm_bw_1 <- lm(purchase_after ~ days_since_last_centered + coupon, df_bw_1)
summary(lm_bw_1)

#>

#> lm(formula = purchase_after ~ days_since_last_centered + coupon, 
#>     data = df_bw_1)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max

#> couponTRUE                 7.4823     1.0771   6.947 9.38e-11 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 3.352 on 157 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.6255, Adjusted R-squared:  0.6208 
#> F-statistic: 131.1 on 2 and 157 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16




# Case of Double the bandwidth
df_bw_below_2 <- coupon %>% filter(days_since_last >= bw_2[1] & days_since_last < c0)
df_bw_above_2 <- coupon %>% filter(days_since_last >= c0 & days_since_last <= bw_2[2])

df_bw_2 <- bind_rows(df_bw_above_2, df_bw_below_2)

lm_bw_2 <- lm(purchase_after ~ days_since_last_centered + coupon, df_bw_2)
summary(lm_bw_2)

#>

#>

#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -12.2718  -2.0858  -0.0003   2.0275  10.6749 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                          Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)              10.61700    0.27386  38.767   <2e-16 ***

#> couponTRUE                9.51584    0.48628  19.569   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

#> F-statistic: 748.6 on 2 and 626 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



Comparing the results from normal, half and double the band width we can see that changing the value from the normal to half the change in the estimate coefficients remain almost unchanged but when the band width is doubled we can see the change. It is important to choose the correct value according to what the ask is.

title: Probability Theory
text:
2.1 Solution:

What is the percentage of customers using all three devices?
0.5%
What is the percentage of customers using at least two devices?
19.9%
What is the percentage of customers using only one device?
80.1%

title: Probability Theory
text:
3.1 Solution:

\(P(\overline A|B)=\frac{0.01*0.96}{(0.01*0.96)+(0.97*0.04)}= 0.1983=19.83\)%

\(P(A|B)= \frac{0.97*0.04}{(0.97*0.04)+(0.01*0.96)}=0.8017=80.17\)%

These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.83 % that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.17% that the product is faulty.

title: Statistical Concepts
text: It doesn’t make sense to compare them since they are individual data sets and the comparison would give us no insight.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
#Compute the covariance and correlation between both variables
covariance <- cov(random_vars$age,random_vars$income)
covariance

#> [1] 29700.15

correlation <- cor(random_vars$age,random_vars$income)
correlation

#> [1] 0.5479432




Covariance: 29700.15

Correlation: 0.5479432

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Covariance indicates the direction of the linear relationship between variables but it doesn’t provide a standardized measure.
Correlation is a standardized measure that ranges between -1 and 1. With -1 indicating a perfect negative linear relationship, 0 indicating no linear relationship and 1 indicating a perfect positive linear relationship.
With the description above, it is easier to interpret the correlation since the values are fixed and we know that the 0.5479 represents a strong linear relation because it is closer to 1. The covariance value since it has no standardized measure, we are unable to know if it is representing a high or low value.

With the code above we can see that the most relevant factor out of all was “engine size” since it has the smallest P-value and its the regressor we will use.


min(car$enginesize)

#> [1] 61

max(car$enginesize)

#> [1] 326



From the glimpse we know that the data type for “engine size” is a double.
The values it can take on we use the min and max functions to know the range of the “engine size”. From 61-326.


Since engine size was the most significant factor, having the lowest p value, which means the price is dependent on it and changing the value would affect the price, when the engine size increases, the price will increase as well.


A low p value provides support for the claim that the alternative hypothesis is true, which means there is a significant correlation between the variables.

title: Causality
text:
Per capita cheese consumption correlates with Number of people who died by becoming tangled in their bedsheets.

library(gridExtra)
# With 10 coordinates from out plot:

cheese_consumption <- c(29.8, 30.1, 30.5, 30.6, 31.3, 31.7, 32.6, 33.1, 32.7, 32.8)
bedsheet_deaths <- c(327, 456, 509, 497, 596, 573, 661, 741, 809, 717)

# Create a data frame
data <- data.frame(Year = seq(2000, 2009), Cheese = cheese_consumption, Bedsheets = bedsheet_deaths)

# Load ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)

# Create a plot for Cheese Consumption
plot_cheese <- ggplot(data, aes(x = Year, y = Cheese)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_line(color = "blue", linetype = "solid") +
  labs(title = "Cheese Consumption Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Cheese Consumption")

# Create a plot for Bedsheet Deaths
plot_bedsheets <- ggplot(data, aes(x = Year, y = Bedsheets)) +
  geom_point(color = "red") +
  geom_line(color = "red", linetype = "dashed") +
  labs(title = "Bedsheet Deaths Over Time",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Bedsheet Deaths")

# Display the plots side by side
gridExtra::grid.arrange(plot_cheese, plot_bedsheets, ncol = 2)

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
A company sells a SaaS (Software as a service) to business clients that chose to subscribe to one of the three subscription levels, Starter, Premium or Elite, which provide different features at different price points (more storage and other capabilities). Starter has the least functionality, while Elite includes the most features.

Now imagine, you are working as an analyst for that company and are asked to examine the relationship between follow-up calls to the clients and their satisfaction with the product and service. Follow-up calls are voluntary and are just to help the client with possible problems and so on. Satisfaction is measured on a weekly basis by surveying the clients.




df <- data.frame(
  follow_ups = c(8, 7, 8, 9, 10, 6, 7, 6, 8, 8, 0, 1, 2, 2, 3),
  satisfaction = c(40, 45, 47, 44, 50, 55, 60, 62, 59, 65, 70, 74, 77, 74, 80),
  subscription = c("Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Elite", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium+", "Premium", "Premium", "Premium", "Premium", "Premium")
)

# Regress satisfaction on follow_ups
model_follow_ups <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
summary(model_follow_ups)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

summary(model_follow_ups)$coefficients["follow_ups", "Pr(>|t|)"]

#> [1] 0.0002426524

# Regress satisfaction on follow_ups and account for subscription
model_subscription <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df)
summary(model_subscription)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08

summary(model_subscription)$coefficients["follow_ups", "Pr(>|t|)"]

#> [1] 0.0168153

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
The coefficient for the satisfaction on follow ups is -3.3093
The coefficient for the satisfaction on follow ups and account for subscription is 2.1944

When follow ups are being done, the level of satisfaction on those is low which is why the coefficient is negative.
When you factor in the subscription the level of satisfaction increases which is why the coefficient is positive.
Since the follow ups are to help the client with possible problems, when they are following up maybe the problems are not solved and the satisfaction of the call would be low. When people have subscriptions their problems might be easier to solve and therefore the overall satisfaction would increase.

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
library(ggplot2)

# Scatter plot with regression line for satisfaction ~ follow_ups
plot_follow_ups <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(title = "Satisfaction vs. Follow-ups",
       x = "Follow-ups",
       y = "Satisfaction")

# Scatter plot with regression line for satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription
plot_subscription <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction, color = subscription)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Satisfaction vs. Follow-ups by Subscription",
       x = "Follow-ups",
       y = "Satisfaction",
       color = "Subscription")

# Display the plots
print(plot_follow_ups)

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'







print(plot_subscription)

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
Imagine you are a business owner of four stores and you want to investigate if there is a benefit of having own parking spots in front of your store. And if there is a benefit, you would also like to know what size it has.
At stores A and B, which are located in the city center, you don’t have any parking spots but at stores. C and D, located outside the city you do. Except for location and parking spots, the stores are very similar, i.e. they sell exactly the same goods, have the same size etc.

Variables:

L-> Location

P-> Parking Spots

A-> Store A
B-> Store B
C-> Store C
D-> Store D
S-> Sales


library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

# create DAG from dagitty
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
L [location,pos="0.9,0.6"]
P [exposure,pos="0.575,0.4"]
S [outcome,pos="0.9,0.4"]
D [pos="0.7,0.2"]
C [pos="0.7,0.3"]
B [pos="0.7,0.5"]
A [pos="0.7,0.6"]
L-> S
P -> B
P-> A
P-> C
P-> D
A -> S
B -> S
C -> S
D -> S
}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag()+
  geom_dag_point(color = "pink") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "black") +
    geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "blue")

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

# Load the dataset
abtest_data <-  readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/abtest_online.rds")
lm_ate <-lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data= abtest_data)
summary(lm_ate)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -16.702 -14.478  -9.626  13.922  64.648 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  16.7017     0.8374  19.944  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE  -7.0756     1.1796  -5.998 2.79e-09 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.65 on 998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0348, Adjusted R-squared:  0.03383 
#> F-statistic: 35.98 on 1 and 998 DF,  p-value: 2.787e-09

compare_prev <- ggplot(abtest_data,
                       aes(x=chatbot,
                           y=previous_visit,
                           color = as.factor(chatbot)))  + 
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Previous_visits", title = "Difference in previous visits")


compare_mobile <- ggplot(abtest_data,
                         aes(x=chatbot,
                             y=mobile_device,
                             color = as.factor(chatbot)))  + 
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Mobile decives", title = "Difference in mobile devices")


compare_outcome <-  ggplot(abtest_data, 
                           aes(x = chatbot, 
                               y = purchase_amount, 
                               color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Purchase Amount", title = "Difference in Purchase Amount")

plot(compare_prev)






plot (compare_mobile) 






plot(compare_outcome)








Covariates are not balanced in the plots.

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
lm_all <- lm(purchase_amount~chatbot+previous_visit+mobile_device, data=abtest_data)
summary(lm_all)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot + previous_visit + mobile_device, 
#>     data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -25.414 -14.428  -8.435  12.559  64.584 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)        15.2840     1.1227  13.614  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE        -6.8488     1.1792  -5.808 8.49e-09 ***
#> previous_visit      0.7792     0.2869   2.716  0.00673 ** 
#> mobile_deviceTRUE  -0.8562     1.2642  -0.677  0.49841    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.6 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04243,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03954 
#> F-statistic: 14.71 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 2.228e-09



We can see that the chatbot coefficient is negative and it has a small p value which would suggest that the chatbot is associated with a statistically significant decrease in the average purchase. Customers with the chatbot tend to make smaller purchases compared to those with human interaction.

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
# Include an interaction term
lm_model <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device, data = abtest_data)
summary(lm_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device, data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#> -16.98 -14.54  -9.95  14.13  65.24 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)                    16.9797     1.0152  16.725   <2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE                    -7.0301     1.4284  -4.922    1e-06 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE              -0.8727     1.7987  -0.485    0.628    
#> chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE  -0.1526     2.5369  -0.060    0.952    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.66 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.03534,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03244 
#> F-statistic: 12.16 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 8.034e-08



As we can see from the summary, both the estimate and p value show us that the interaction between chatbot and mobile users has no statistically significant effect on making a purchase.

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
#Logistic regression
logistic_model <- glm(purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
                      data = abtest_data, 
                      family = binomial(link = 'logit'))
summary(logistic_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)       -0.22185    0.12347  -1.797  0.07237 .  
#> chatbotTRUE       -0.96894    0.13564  -7.144 9.09e-13 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE -0.07119    0.14530  -0.490  0.62417    
#> previous_visit     0.10606    0.03262   3.252  0.00115 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 1329.1  on 999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 1262.2  on 996  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 1270.2
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4

# Extract coefficient for chatbot
chatbot_coefficient <- coef(logistic_model)["chatbotTRUE"]
# Calculate odds ratio
odds_ratio <- exp(chatbot_coefficient)


The coefficient for chatbot in the logistic model is -0.969 which means that for users that are exposed to the chatbot, the odds of making a purchase decrease by 0.969 units compared to those not exposed to it. If we exponentiate the coefficient will give us the odds ratio of 0.379 which tells us that the odds of making a purchase for users exposed to the chatbot are 0.379 times the odds for the users with human interaction.

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
C -> card
A -> age
S -> sex
PAP -> Pre Average Purchase (pre_abg_purch)
AP -> Average Purchase (avg_purch)


library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(ggplot2)
library(MatchIt)
library(tidyverse)
# Load the dataset
membership_data <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/membership.rds")

# Define DAG
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
AP [avgpur,pos="0.9,0.6"]
PAP [preavgpur,pos="0.6,0.4"]
C [card,pos="0.9,0.4"]
A [pos="0.7,0.6"]
S [pos="0.7,0.2"]

C-> AP
PAP -> C
A-> C
S-> C
A-> PAP
S -> PAP

}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag()+
  geom_dag_point(color = "pink") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "red")









lm_model <- lm(avg_purch ~  card, data = membership_data)
summary(lm_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = membership_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -101.515  -20.684   -0.199   20.424  120.166 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  65.9397     0.3965  166.29   <2e-16 ***
#> card         25.2195     0.6095   41.38   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 30.11 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.1462, Adjusted R-squared:  0.1461 
#> F-statistic:  1712 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

coefficients <- coef(lm_model)
print(coefficients)

#> (Intercept)        card 
#>    65.93965    25.21950




(Coarsened) Exact Matching.


#CEM
cem <- matchit(card ~ avg_purch + age + pre_avg_purch + sex,
               data = membership_data, 
               method = 'cem', 
               estimand = 'ATE')
df_cem <- match.data(cem)
model_cem<- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
summary (model_cem)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -162.422  -19.058    0.153   18.795  147.646 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  75.9624     0.4051 187.526   <2e-16 ***
#> card          0.9485     0.6212   1.527    0.127    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 28.34 on 8515 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0002737,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.0001563 
#> F-statistic: 2.332 on 1 and 8515 DF,  p-value: 0.1268



Nearest-Neighbor Matching.


#Nearest Neighbor
nn <- matchit(card ~ avg_purch + pre_avg_purch + sex + age,
              data = membership_data,
              method = "nearest", # changed
              distance = "mahalanobis", # changed
              replace = T)
df_nn <- match.data(nn)
nn_model <- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df_nn, weights = weights)
summary(nn_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_nn, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -101.515  -22.370   -3.279   16.475  178.481 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  90.2268     0.6438 140.155   <2e-16 ***
#> card          0.9324     0.7939   1.174     0.24    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#>

#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0002143,  Adjusted R-squared:  5.895e-05 
#> F-statistic: 1.379 on 1 and 6434 DF,  p-value: 0.2403



Inverse Probability Weighting.


# Inverse Probability Weighting
model_prop <- glm(card ~ avg_purch + sex + age + pre_avg_purch,
                  data=membership_data,
                  family = binomial(link="logit"))
df_aug <- membership_data %>% mutate(propensity = predict(model_prop, type = "response"))

#Extend data by IPW scores:
df_ipw <- df_aug %>% mutate(
  ipw = (card/propensity) + ((1-card) / (1-propensity)))

#Estimation
model_ipw <- lm(avg_purch ~ card,
                data = df_ipw, 
                weights = ipw)

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
C -> card
A -> age
S -> sex
PAP -> Pre Average Purchase (pre_abg_purch)
AP -> Average Purchase (avg_purch)


library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(ggplot2)
library(MatchIt)
library(tidyverse)
# Load the dataset
membership_data <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/membership.rds")

# Define DAG
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
AP [avgpur,pos="0.9,0.6"]
PAP [preavgpur,pos="0.6,0.4"]
C [card,pos="0.9,0.4"]
A [pos="0.7,0.6"]
S [pos="0.7,0.2"]

C-> AP
PAP -> C
A-> C
S-> C
A-> PAP
S -> PAP

}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag()+
  geom_dag_point(color = "pink") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "red")

title: Difference-in-Differences
text:
library(tidyverse)

#Load the data 
Hospitals <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/hospdd.rds")

# Manually compute differences
# Step 1: Difference between treatment and control group BEFORE treatment
before_control_A <- Hospitals %>%
  filter(hospital >= 19 & hospital<= 46, procedure == 0) %>% 
  pull(satis)

before_treatment_A <- Hospitals %>%
  filter(hospital >= 1 & hospital<=18, procedure == 0) %>% 
  pull(satis)

diff_before_A <- before_treatment_A - before_control_A

#> Warning in before_treatment_A - before_control_A: longitud de objeto mayor no
#> es múltiplo de la longitud de uno menor

# Step 2: Difference between treatment and control group AFTER treatment
after_control_A <- rep(0, dim(Hospitals)[1])

after_treatment_A <- Hospitals  %>%
  filter(hospital >= 1 & hospital<=18, procedure == 1) %>% 
  pull(satis)

diff_after_A <- after_treatment_A - after_control_A

#> Warning in after_treatment_A - after_control_A: longitud de objeto mayor no es
#> múltiplo de la longitud de uno menor

# Step 3: Difference-in-differences.
diff_diff_A <- diff_after_A - diff_before_A

#> Warning in diff_after_A - diff_before_A: longitud de objeto mayor no es
#> múltiplo de la longitud de uno menor

sprintf("Estimate: %.2f", diff_diff_A)

month + hospital: treats months and hospitals as numeric variables and assumes a linear relationship between them. The coefficient estimation is separate for each month and hospital
as.factor treats the months and hospitals as factors which allows non-linear relationships. It estimates separate fixed effects for each month and hospital

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
NF: New Feature
PU: Pop Up
UC: Unobserved Characteristics
ST: Screen Time


library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(estimatr)

#Load the data
App <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/rand_enc.rds")

# Define DAG
dag_model <- 'dag {
bb="0,0,1,1"
NF [avgpur,pos="0.7,0.4"]
UC [preavgpur,pos="0.8,0.6"]
ST [card,pos="0.9,0.4"]
PU [pos="0.6,0.4"]

UC-> NF
UC -> ST
NF -> ST
NF -> PU


}
'
# draw DAG
ggdag(dag_model) +
  theme_dag()+
  geom_dag_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "white") +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "green")

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
#Compute the naive, biased estimate
lm_naive <- lm(time_spent ~ used_ftr, data = App)
summary(lm_naive)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = time_spent ~ used_ftr, data = App)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -20.4950  -3.5393   0.0158   3.5961  20.5051 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) 18.86993    0.06955   271.3   <2e-16 ***
#> used_ftr    10.82269    0.10888    99.4   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 5.351 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.497,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.497 
#> F-statistic:  9881 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
#Correlation computation
cor_matrix <- cor(App)
print(cor_matrix)

#>             rand_enc  used_ftr time_spent
#> rand_enc   1.0000000 0.2044110  0.1296716
#> used_ftr   0.2044110 1.0000000  0.7050147
#> time_spent 0.1296716 0.7050147  1.0000000

app_corr <- App %>%
  filter(used_ftr == 1)
cor(app_corr$rand_enc,app_corr$time_spent)

#> [1] -0.02744462

#First Stage
first_stage <- lm(used_ftr~time_spent, data = App)
summary(first_stage)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = used_ftr ~ time_spent, data = App)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -1.1469 -0.2593 -0.0247  0.2592  1.1636 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) -0.661420   0.011309  -58.48   <2e-16 ***
#> time_spent   0.045926   0.000462   99.40   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 0.3486 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.497,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.497 
#> F-statistic:  9881 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

# Predicted 'probabilities' from first stage
pred_fs <- predict(first_stage)

# Create table with predictions and actual decisions
pred_vs_actl <- tibble(
  pred = pred_fs,
  actl = App$used_ftr
)

# Plot predictions vs original
ggplot(pred_vs_actl, aes(x = pred, y = actl, color = as.factor(actl))) +
  geom_jitter(alpha = .5) +
  scale_color_discrete(labels = c("Control Group", "Treatment Group")) +
  theme(legend.title = element_blank())






# Second stage
second_stage <- lm(App$time_spent ~ first_stage$fitted.values)
summary(second_stage)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = App$time_spent ~ first_stage$fitted.values)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>       Min        1Q    Median        3Q       Max 
#> -8.30e-15 -1.40e-15 -7.00e-16 -1.00e-16  5.58e-12 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                            Estimate Std. Error   t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)               1.440e+01  8.900e-16 1.618e+16   <2e-16 ***
#> first_stage$fitted.values 2.177e+01  1.663e-15 1.309e+16   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 5.761e-14 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:      1,  Adjusted R-squared:      1 
#> F-statistic: 1.715e+32 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



IV estimation can provide more credible causal estimates if the 5-prerequisites (Stable unit treatment value assumption, Independence assumption, Exclusion restriction, Instrument relevance and Monotonicity assumption) are met.

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
model_iv <- iv_robust(time_spent ~ used_ftr | rand_enc, data = App)
summary(model_iv)

#> 
#> Call:
#> iv_robust(formula = time_spent ~ used_ftr | rand_enc, data = App)
#> 
#> Standard error type:  HC2 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value  Pr(>|t|) CI Lower CI Upper   DF
#> (Intercept)   19.312     0.2248   85.89 0.000e+00   18.872    19.75 9998
#> used_ftr       9.738     0.5353   18.19 8.716e-73    8.689    10.79 9998
#> 
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.4921 ,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.492 
#> F-statistic:   331 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



coefIV<- coef(model_iv)
print(coefIV)

#> (Intercept)    used_ftr 
#>   19.312415    9.738175

coefNB<- coef(lm_naive)
print(coefNB)

#> (Intercept)    used_ftr 
#>    18.86993    10.82269



The naive estimate is biased if there are unobserved confounders influencing both the treatment assignment and the outcome. The instrumental variable estimate aims to address this bias by using an instrument that is correlated with the treatment but is not directly related to the outcome, except through its effect on the treatment.
Comparing these estimates, it seems that the naive estimate is larger than the IV estimate. If the instrument is valid (i.e., it satisfies the necessary assumptions), the IV estimate is often considered less biased than the naive estimate. Therefore, it is possible that the naive estimate has an upward bias.

title: Regression Discontinuity
section: 2.1 Use a plot to confirm your argument.
text:
2.1 Use a plot to confirm your argument.

library(rddensity)
library(tidyverse)

Shipping <- readRDS("D:/GitHub/cdsba-pamoviedo/Causal_Data_Science_Data/shipping.rds")

#Define cut-off
co <- 30

#Density Test
rddd <- rddensity(Shipping$purchase_amount, c = co)
summary(rddd)

P-value is 0 which would indicate there is a statistically significant difference at the cutoff. That supports the idea that purchases with amounts greater than 30€ have a different impact than those at or below 30€. (Since shipping is free for those orders above 30€). Taking this into consideration we can use purchase amount as a running variable.
